reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: The Howler
Original Release: 2014
Genre Tags: 2D; Simple; Puzzle; Strategy
My Overall Grade: B-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 2 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Casual gamers
REVIEWI love epic AAA titles that take three full work-weeks to complete just as much as the next guy; but sometimes I also enjoy those short and simple games that are easy to digest after a long day. The Howler is a great example of the latter. It has simple, straightforward mechanics with a pleasing, intimate art style. It is short and gratifyingly challenging without being too frustrating. And there is also an optional Voice-Mode which can be used to add a little dash of flavor to the experience.

The game is comprised of a small amount of short levels. Most of them won’t take long to beat. The puzzles involve simple two-dimensional movement which requires timing and precision. It is all very simplistic. But if you want to try out something a little different, you can enable Voice-Mode, which will allow you to use your voice (via humming, whistling, or blowing into the microphone) to control the game. It’s kind of fun at first, but some of the harder levels require a lot of precision and it can be real difficult in Voice-Mode.

The hand-drawn artwork is also very nice.  It is a pleasing mix of intimate, curious, and casual. It isn’t the most refined or aweing art, but it is unique and full of character, and it fits the game well.

The last thing I’ll mention is that it is very short. To me, short games are great because I love variety and hate leaving things unfinished; but I know some people may have a problem with it, so be aware. Also, I generally try to not discuss price in my reviews, because everyone values a dollar differently depending on their lifestyle. But in this case I do want to say that I feel like the developers have priced this game reasonably considering its length. And so, like I suggested earlier: it is a nice, little game for those times you want something lightweight and intuitive. If that sounds like something you would be interested in, I would recommend you give The Howler some consideration.

DISCLAIMER: I was given a key for free by the publisher!

The most outstanding feature of The Howler is the art style for sure. Hand drawn art for both background and foreground objects. The later actually appear like paper cut-outs attached to the former.

Gameplay is simple and straight forward! You are only required to click the left mouse button to control your balloon (click = balloon will rise, no-lick = balloon will drop). Movement to the left/right is controlled by flowing air currents; e.g. if you want to move to the right, just let the balloon rise or drop to the corresponding current, but beware of sharp objects that will let it burst by touching.
The object in each level varies from simply getting to the landing spot to picking up packes, dropping them off and land.

As much as I enjoy my time with The Howler, there is one important thing to mention, which might be shortcoming for some people: There is NO REAL FULLSCREEN support, that is, even if you go fullscreen, the game itself takes place in a realtively small window!

reviewText:
I will admit, I only bothered to look at this game due to its very cool graphical style. Though, on watching the gameplay video and reading the main synopsis present on the store page, I became fearful of a very real possibility. Namely, that hiding behind an excellent artistic direction is a shallow, and probably irritating, gimmick driven “game”. Not unexpectedly, I’m obliged to report that my suspicions proved accurate, but also that my discoveries come with several reservations.

First, the gameplay itself (and this should be obvious from the accompanying trailers), is minimal. The goal is to slowly raise and lower your balloon in tune with the weather patterns, which push you left and right, to varying degrees, and land at some designated point. As the game goes on, you’ll have to contend with the added complexity of doing this several times per level, and occasionally even drop things down holes or bombs on unsuspecting flying spiky balls. Playing with a standard mouse, this gets boring, and at times irritating, though mostly due to the slow nature of your balloon and having to wait for your chance to fail again. Chances are, you will have to reset levels several times due to popping or floating too far off-screen. This is where the gimmick comes in, and the developers clearly hope that people haven’t learned from every other throwaway peripheral and gimmick that console makers try to push down our throats. By using your mic, you can control the balloon with your voice. Or any manner of sound, I suppose, so long as you can easily fluctuate it. This is also where my first aforementioned reservation comes in. If you can entertain yourself for hours on end by making stupid noises in the dark, than by all means, play and thoroughly enjoy The Howler. If you’re considering this as a fun diversion for you and your drunk friends, ask yourself this – when was the last time you were able to keep a group of drunks quiet for more than 5 seconds? If you can’t answer that question, than you’re better dusting off the ol’ Kinect for another go around of drunk digital soccer.

Now here’s my second reservation: the art design. It is superb, often ranging from the melancholy to the downright foreboding. And of course, the Wolf. It really bothers me that such a fantastic art style is wasted on a game like this. Given that this mediocre excursion could be beaten in little more than hour (provided you’re forced to reset as often as I had to), than I would seriously consider recommending this title given you have a fondness for such things. If you can forgive, or at the very least tolerate the gameplay, than you may have a better time than I did, if only for the joy of viewing the set pieces. Know, though, that for some reason the game is limited to a small window (surrounded by a large black border in fullscreen), and cannot appear to be changed. While this keeps the art crisp and clean, I am disappointed that I couldn’t have a closer look at some of the better murals.

The Howler is based off of a book, and you’ll see a direct link to it on Amazon.com in the game’s menu. It’s a shame that there is absolutely no exposition or plot to the game’s events, offering only a quick phrase explaining your mission for whatever group and off you go!. Perhaps it might have alleviated the boredom of the actual gameplay mechanic to have given it all a more defined purpose. In any case, The Howler is something you probably shouldn’t even bother playing in the first place. Unless you really think you’re going to enjoy making stupid noises into your mic for an hour, or absolutely refuse to use google to find the game’s sublime artwork, I’d recommend you at least find a better mobile port to spend your time on.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
The Howler is a short indie hot air balloon simulator developed by Antanas Marcelionis and released in mid 2014.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: There is a progressive story about the “Viceroy of Vilnius, Antanas Sidabras”, that is told through the 15 levels of the game. (not including bonus levels)
Aesthetically speaking, the game has some really visually interesting graphics; the art is hand drawn and the “architecture actually exists in Vilnius today”, according to Antanas Marcelionis.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=508269784

Gameplay: There are two control choices: the volume of your voice (obviously requiring a functional microphone on your computer), when the microphone picks up your voice being loud enough, your hot air balloon goes up.
Alternatively, simply use a keyboard, pressing space to go up, and then any other key drops your cargo (including your Steam screenshot button, so beware the screenshot!)
You need to dodge objects that may pop your balloon, and move into air currents that will push you to the right or left. While the game is very straightforward and controls very easily, it's definitely not an “easy” game.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=508264819

Achievements: There are no steam achievements for The Howler, quite frankly there isn't enough game to give very many achievements. If achievements were added at some point, it would be along the lines of “beat the game”, “find the hidden level codes”, and anything else would be along the lines of high score".

reviewText:
From the start, I knew that playing The Howler would prove to be quite a challenge for me and I was right.  It's a very different game from the ones I usually play but after having played through the majority of the levels, I found myself liking the challenge despite the difficulty.

Basically, the gameplay is seemingly simple.  You have to navigate your hot air balloon throughout the city of Vilnius, completing various missions and so forth.  Either you can use your mouse or your voice to navigate the balloon.  However, for the latter, a microphone is required and as I didn't have one at the time I'm posting this review, I had to go with the mouse.  (For the remainder of my review, I'll describe it using the mouse.)  How high or low your balloon goes depends on whether you press your mouse button and how much you do so as well as when to let it go.  You have to deal with the wind currents and do your best to avoid obstacles that will make your balloon pop.

Although The Howler seems like a simple game, I found it quite difficult and to the point of frustration at times.  Then again, I may simply not be used to this kind of game.  Nevertheless, I would have found it helpful if there had been some tips on how to play the game, as they would have made it easier to play.  On some good points, though, I did enjoy the art of this game.  It is quite beautiful and worth seeing.  The music was fun as well.  As for the levels, I found that I could end up skipping some if they proved to be too difficult.  Now I don't know if this is a bug but I liked that I didn't have to play through all the levels to unlock everything.  In the end, I suppose that's why I'll give this game a positive rating.

I would recommend The Howler if you want to try a unique game and one which you would wish to play occasionally.  If you are adept at using the mouse, it won't take long to complete it but if not, it will prove to be challenging.

reviewText:
Life as air-balloon pilot is tough.  You aren't afforded any of those nifty steering doo-dads.  All you have to guide you is the wind.  Playing The Howler is all about learning to become one with the wind as you soar around this pastel world.  Its a simple concept for a game but it comes together quite well.  Its a short but sweet ride that should keep you entertained for just over an hour.

The controls are super simple.  All you can do is increase the heat to ascend or subsequently release the hot air to descend.  By controlling the elevation you will pass through different zones of air blowing the wind this way and that way.  Certain currents will be stronger than other and you must be careful of the potential momentum of the stronger winds.  By straddling these currents you can proceed to your destination or pick up goods required for the different objectives.

Many levels will simply have to going for one spot to another.  Other levels may have you pick up and deliver a package.  Later in the game you'll be given bombs you can drop.  Use these to destroy obstacles in your path or take out the enemy's bridge.  Just be careful not to be too close to your bombs as you can easily be sent floating off screen and into the abyss.

One of the coolest parts of the game is the hand drawn art.  The backgrounds are gorgeous and rich with detail.  They distinguish themselves nicely from the sharp,clean, lines of the objects in the foreground.  There isn't much to the sound design.  There isn't any music while playing which could be justified to help you concentrate.  Usually all you hear is balloon's propane kicking in as you turn on the heat to ascend.  That being said the automatons and cars really stick out in the levels they're present.

There really isn't much else to say.  This is a really simple game, one that doesn't take long to finish.  That isn't necessary a bad thing considering the low price point.  Not to mention there really isn't many other games like it.  The unique art style might make it worth considering if you're on edge.  As long as you're not expecting anything too fancy there is fun to be had playing The Howler.

reviewText:
Awoo?

Basic Breakdown: Developed by Antanas Marcelionis and Renė Petrulienė, published by Antanas Marcelionis The Howler is an adventure puzzle game with a set of interesting, unusual, unforgiving and complex puzzles that will have you frustrated many a times.

You control your air balloon through a series of 'missions' to either deliver packages, blow up automatons or just land atop another air ship as the winds play havoc with your flight path.

Pro Tip - To unlock the final puzzle, the code is -sos-

Menu: Honestly, there isn't really one which is slightly bothersome. Especially when it comes to wanting to remap certain keys that are to do with steam. Taking screenshots while you have a package or a bomb will instantly release them, interfering with your mission.

Graphics/Art: All art used in the Howler was meticulously created by classically-trained painters. Most of the art was thanks to Rene Petruliene: all the graphic design was drawn by hand, giving it that extra classic, renaissance feel.

Soundtrack: It ties in with the aesthetics of the game so well. It gives it that timely atmospheric feel that just works.

Final Conclusion: Great, fairly short puzzler that will keep you entertained and frustrated depending on how good you are at controlling your air balloon. Also has a nifty unique feature of being able to control your flight with voice/sound from your headset which I quite enjoy because it keeps things interesting.

Completing a mission will leave you feeling satisfied and accomplished, which for me is very rare. Props to the devs for making such a well balanced game that is entertaining, has wonderful art that clearly shows a lot of work and initiative went into it, for making something really unique and a nice cross of difficult but not punishing.

As must for any puzzle fans out there.

reviewText:
(This copy of the game was provided freely by EpicQuest Games)

I don't particularly like to ragequit a game, but this is the first one that's driven me to do so in a while.

The Howler has a lot of things a good game should have. There's the unique concept of using your voice (or noise in general) to move your hot air balloon around the map. The artwork is beautiful and really worth taking a good time to enjoy. That's where it stops. Right there is where The Howler ceases and I find myself completely irritated with the game.

There is simplicity in the game. You are delivering parcels and you don't want your balloon oblierated on the ornate and breath-taking buildings. That's great and that would appeal to a wide audience there. That's perfect. Yet here's what flubs it up. The wind and weather direction should be something that gives you a slight challenge, not forces you to constantly restart the level because the angle wasn't just perfect so your balloon didn't pop or you didn't fly too high into the heavens. I've played similar games to this before and especially when you're starting out, they're a lot more forgiving with their wind merchanics. The Howler punishes you mercilessly on level 3 and continues to kick you in the stomach with that mechanic until you've had enough and switch the game off.

There's also the fact that the voice control, even when your microphone is on the most sensitivity possible, will not be enough to keep your balloon afloat. Now I'm aware that the game suggested I scream, but not everyone using Steam is living in a house where we have enough privacy to scream. If I have to make my voice raw to get that thing off the ground, why am I playing the game at all? That's entirely too much work and I'm not getting a sore throat just to play it.

The screens betwen levels are charming and give me the option to turn off the microphone (your mouse will be easier to play with at this rate, I suppose!) but little exposition except a bit of real life history of the city. There's no actual substansial story here and I was expecting a tiny bit more, given I felt teased with the artwork and fairly let down by game play.

It's like a really pretty flappy bird with a harder obstacle course you're supposed to scream at. I just didn't feel the need to open my big trap since it doesn't actually help!

Accessibility warnings? Transition screens are bright and have a white light. May cause migraines or seizures if you're sensitive. It certainly brought me a migraine. The repetitive motion of clicking upward gets sore (and pretty old!) fast as well.

reviewText:
The Howler is a game of dexterity and timing in which you control a hot air balloon. Clicking the mouse (or making noise if you have a compatible microphone) makes the balloon go up. In each level, you need to manoeuvre the balloon through a parcours by making use of the wind. There are areas in which the wind blows the balloon forward and there are areas in which the wind blows the balloon back.

At first, this simple idea looks promising. The first few levels are fun. But soon, the real difficulty pops up: level after level, you need to manoeuvre the balloon through spikey things. And the balloon snaps on the slightest contact with spikey things, so it requires perfect timing. At that point, you realize the game is actually a lot like an unforgiving old-school platformer game. You know, a game that requires you to try and try again until you pretty much know the exact timing to get through each level. I'm sure a lot of people enjoy games like that, and they will enjoy The Howler for what it is, but I think it's only fair to warn other people about the nature of this game because it doesn't show from the description and the screenshots.

What you can tell from watching the screenshots, is that the artwork is very nice and pretty unique for an indie game like this. It's also a cheap game, especially when on sale, so if you're not sure whether to try it after reading this and some other reviews, I'd say give it a go. But because the Howler is not the sort of game I expected and because I simply didn't enjoy the game for what it turned out to be, I can't generally recommend this game so I feel obligated to click the 'thumbs down' button.

reviewText:
The game has a wonderful art style which is a combination of hand sketching and watercolor wash. The setting is steampunk and you play as a hotair balloon pilot. You have some control over the upward and downward motion of the balloon but you are at the mercy of the wind currents to move left and right. You will need to use momentum to navigate around obstacles, using the wind to your advantage and quickly changing elevation. The difficulty of the game ramps up quite quickly. On most levels (missions) you will be picking up and/or dropping parcels. There is a great deal of verticality in the game and often your destinations will be outside of your view. Each mission starts with a quick scan over the scene, but it will be up to you to remember where you need to go. You can control the game with your mouse and keyboard, but you can also control it with your voice. I tried this feature but found it less appealing than traditional controls. The game has a 4x3 aspect ratio and is locked at 30 FPS. I suspect this is due to it being available on iOS as well. Given how the level design works they would not have been able to simply expand the aspect ratio. This may be off-putting to some but the game can run in windowed mode so you won't notice any wasted space. In full screen you will have black bars on the sides. You cannot control the volume in the game, you'll have to rely on the system sound controls. This is probably another aspect of its iOS support.

Overall I enjoyed my time with the game so far and I will play more of it. If you like to be in complete control of your character" you may not enjoy this title since a lot of the time the control is out of your hands.

reviewText:
In this air current and physics based game you will have to navigate safely through level upon level completing tasks while on the clock. In this 2D game you will spend most of your time in a hot air balloon where you will have to master the different speeds of the air currents while taking into consideration that air can blow in both directions.

Graphically The Howler definitely has that aged look to it. I don't mean that it looks dated it just looks more like a steam-punk Victorian age type of feel. One of the things I like about the art style in this game is that it gives you the look of a city or area of the city while not overly cluttering up the screen.

This game is basically played with just a couple of buttons and/or your voice. I know that sounds a bit crazy, but if you have a good enough mic you can issues increases and decreases in altitude by the level of your voice. Do you want to go higher, get louder, you want to descend, well just get quieter. I wouldn't recommend being silent that might cause a not so fun crash, but hey you never know until you try it.

One of the things that really impressed me with The Howler was the fact that if you had the tutorial text on you could easily pick up this game and be able to play it. Now I know that there are games that put you through the tutorial once and then disable, but in this game it doesn't and that's not a problem. Instead of constantly taking the player out of the game by throwing up dialogue boxes that you have to click ok or next on they put the text into the background of the game and once you start moving around it just vanishes.

Now there is a slight downside to this game and that is it DEFINITELY feels like a port of a tablet or phone game. The resolution for the game can't be changed so you'll be faced with playing in a small box on your screen. The other thing is that as easy as the controls are for some reason the mouse button just doesn't seem to translate as well as say a tap and hold on a touchscreen, maybe that's just me, but I think it makes a difference.

So if you are looking for a challenging puzzle game to play with some interesting yet simple controls you are going to want to pick up this game. I'm not going to lie there are definitely some of the levels where it took me more tries than it should have, but that sense of accomplishment when you do gain enough speed to negate the wind going the opposite direction, or the precision flying/floating required to navigate treacherous locations is pretty astounding. So with that I'm giving this game a 7.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
TL;DR = Basically Flappy Bird 2.0 XL... With a hand-drawn art style that looks steampunkish

The Howler is simple: there is only one button to control: Click to make the balloon go up, do NOT click to make it drop. Different wind layers (of different strengths) means you will move left or right depending on the altitude. You move the balloon from launch pad to destination pad. As you work your way through the over a dozen missions (and there's a bit of a plot) you get complications, like more wind layers, requirement to pick up one or more cargo packs at an intermediate platform, and later, airborne obstacles that gets in your way. A light touch of your balloon against something is okay, heavier touch and your balloon goes POOF.

The difficulty curve feels rather uneven. There's a mission at about halfway where you need to land the balloon, with 2 cargo boxes loaded, THROUGH the mouth of a statue (going at a diagonal). Somehow the balloon felt much more delicate. I made it once without the cargo, but can not make it with the cargo after over a dozen attempts.

Still, as a simple and cheap game it does provide an interesting challenge.

The Howler, a game where you can scream as loud as your heart desires, and to this day, the only game (which I have played) where actually screaming of rage, can help you pass a level.

Graphics - Wow, just wow, every single thing here is hand drawn. Only by the sheer amount of detail, you know that those guys who did this, really poured their hearts into it. And once again for the painters wow. 9/10

Story - Couldn't quite understand the story, because it is mostly given to you by little chunks of story, at the start of every level. That is probably done to not spoil the book it is based of off/on, yes you heard right, a book. ''Hour of the Wolf'' by Andrius B. Tapinas. (Now I don't know, if I can post links which are not directly connected to steam, I may be mistaken) You can find the book on Amazon, for a pretty cheap price I might add. (The score is based on playing only the GAME, it may change when I get and read the book.) 5/10

Content - A few levels, but as you progress through the game, more and more mechanics are unlocked, which make every single new level, something new to be experienced. 7/10

Controls - Done by the mouse or your own voice, or any sound that you make, be that bashing your head on the desk (don't do that) or by breaking every single bone in your body (or that). Press and hold to go up, let go to go down or scream to go up, don't scream to go down. Just by having the option of using sound as a way to control the game, it gets an easy 8/10.

Gameplay - Simple, but effective. Also well paced, but I do warn you, some levels need a little bit more thinking to get through. Remember, if what you are doing does not work, try and think of a solution, rather than raging. Also I have a little pro tip for the game, to stop getting your blump to go up from the sound, just unplug your microphone. I know genius. 7/10

A really well made game. Bonus points for making the game small, which in contrast makes the players want to read the book, to understand the story, really well thought out. Also I do encourage people who liked the game, to give the book a try, this is not from a person who has read the book, but from a person who will most definitely read it. Also on a side note, it does not hurt to read overall.

Final Score: 7.2/10

reviewText:
The Howler
This review was last edited after I had completed the first 15 levels

Short Review
A delightful game with beautiful, hand drawn graphics & simple game play that whilst only mildly challenging is fun to play none the less.

Long Review
There is no tutorial but adequate hints are provided in the first few levels and the game play is so simple the lack of a tutorial is not an issue.

The game is set in 2D with beautiful, hand drawn graphics. The game play is simple. You control a got air balloon that you must direct from one point to another, performing simple tasks like dropping off parcels along the way. The audio is restricted to sound effects which are fairly limited but effective.

The controls are simple, for vertical control you press the left mouse button to ignite the hot air and raise and stop pressing it to allow gravity to take over. For left and right control you must rely on the wind direction and speed which varies at different altitudes and is indicated by an arrow on the left hand side; the number of feathers in the quill indicating the strength. Thus you need to be at the correct altitude to move in the correct direction. The SPACE BAR is used to drop objects you are carrying and there is a pause button click able by the mouse.

You cannot pan around so you only see a screens worth of the level around the current location of the balloon. If you go too high, low, left or right and disappear off the edge of the level you die. Similarly if the balloon hits other objects you will usually die.

As you progress through levels additional obstacles like floating bombs are introduced. Fortunately these move in a predictable manner.

The only way to play is via a campaign of different screen levels you play in order (although once you have completed a level you can replay it at any time). The levels are pretty small (maybe twice the width of the monitor).

When you start a new level you are quickly shown what needs to be done by the camera panning about and short text messages appearing. You have a set time limit to complete the tasks.

This game play is short and the game can be easily be completed in 2-3 hours. Ignore my 17 hours game play - I left the game running in the start menu overnight by mistake.

ProsBeautiful, hand drawn graphics
Simple game playConsThe sequence at the start of a level to show you what to do moves along a little fast for me to read all of the textMarks Out Of 5
